index.heading1: The process for Nationally Significant Infrastructure Projects (NSIPs)

preApplication.paragraph1: This is where the applicant starts to create their application. The applicant is required to consult with people and organisations in the area. They must also create detailed documents about the impact the project could have on the environment.
preApplication.paragraph2: It is important to get involved at this stage to influence the application before the applicant sends it to the Planning Inspectorate.
preApplication.linkText: Find out what you can do at this stage and check our detailed guides.

acceptance.paragraph1: This is when the applicant sends us their application documents. We check if we can accept the application for examination. We have 28 days to make this decision.
acceptance.linkText: How the acceptance stage works and what happens next.

preExamination.paragraph1: The Examining Authority is appointed and is made up of one or more inspectors. Anyone who wants to have their say needs to register at this stage.
preExamination.paragraph2: The applicant must publish that the application has been accepted by us. They include when and how parties can register to get involved. The time period for registering is set by the applicant but must be no less than 30 days.
preExamination.paragraph3: The pre-examination stage usually takes about 3 months.
preExamination.linkText: What happens during the pre-examination stage.

examination.paragraph1: The Examining Authority will ask questions about the proposed development. The applicant and anyone who has registered to have their say can get involved and submit comments at each deadline in the timetable. You can also attend hearings that may take place. This stage takes up to 6 months.
examination.linkText: What happens at the examination stage?

recommendation.paragraph1: The Examining Authority writes its recommendation report. This must be completed and sent to the relevant Secretary of State within 3 months of the end of examination stage.

decision.paragraph1: The decision stage is when the relevant Secretary of State then reviews the report and makes the final decision. They have 3 months to make a decision.

postDecision.heading1: What happens after the decision is made
postDecision.paragraph1: Once the Secretary of State has made a decision, challenges can be made to the High Court. All procedures must be followed when making a challenge. The High Court will decide if there are grounds for a judicial review.
postDecision.linkText: What you can do after the decision has been made.

preApplication.paragraph1: The applicant plans their application to make a change to the Development Consent Order (DCO).
preApplication.paragraph2: They carry out consultations and publicise the proposed application. This includes gathering information about how the changes to the project could affect the local environment.
preApplication.paragraph3: It is important to get involved at this stage to influence the application before the applicant sends it to the Planning Inspectorate.

applicationReceived.paragraph1: We will publish the application when we receive it.

applicationPublished.paragraph1: The applicant notifies anyone who has been consulted and publicises the fact that they have made an application. This must include how and when parties can register to get involved. The time period for registering is set by the applicant but must be no less than 28 days.
applicationPublished.paragraph2: Anyone who wants to have their say needs to register at this stage.
applicationPublished.paragraph3: After the registration period has closed, the Secretary of State will review the application. They will decide whether the application needs to be examined in detail.
applicationPublished.paragraph4: If the Secretary of State believes an examination is not required, they'll ask for more information before they make a decision.
applicationPublished.paragraph5: If an examination is required, they'll appoint an Examining Body to carry this out.

examination.paragraph1: The Examining Body asks questions about the proposed changes to the Development Consent Order.
examination.paragraph2: The applicant and anyone who has registered to have their say can get involved and submit comments at each deadline in the timetable. You can also attend hearings that may take place.
examination.paragraph3: This stage takes up to 4 months.

recommendation.paragraph1: The Examining Body writes its recommendation report. This must be completed and sent to the relevant Secretary of State within 2 months of the end of examination stage.

decision.paragraph1: The relevant Secretary of State makes the final decision.
decision.paragraph2: They'll consider the relevant representations received.
decision.paragraph3: If an examination was required, the decision will be based on the recommendation report.
decision.paragraph4: The Secretary of State has 2 months to make a decision.

postDecision.heading1: What happens after the decision is made
postDecision.paragraph1: Once the Secretary of State has made a decision, challenges can be made to the High Court. All procedures must be followed when making a challenge. The High Court will decide if there are grounds for a judicial review.
